body: Well that might be true for simple cases in general. However if there are multiple rules in place and multiple triggers firing the activation poll can become confusing. Maybe a column "triggered by" helps..?

Please note that also, if someone provides a genuinely new utility action in swift (i.e., not a duplicate function, but a new unique function) then we may choose to accept the pull request, BUT it would be better to be consistent to encourage the use of  the same language runtime for all "utils" and encourage all contributions to "utils" or "system" to continue to be in javascript.
This is already fixed

Root cause is that we specify to strict version of ansible `2.0.2.0-1ppa~trusty`
this version is not longer available, 
It should be more relax the version like `2.*`
If a swift developer wants to test an action sequence locally using these utils they will need the swift implementations otherwise the testing burden is increased.
@lehoanganh @domdom82

HI Matt I think since the code got done, I think it's useful to have these actions around and not delete them. They also serve as test fixtures for testing swift in openwhisk.

They currently don't get installed, maybe they can be moved to samples if you think that would be better and more discoverable.
actually it needs to be at least 2.0.2.0 I wonder why they keep throwing out previous versions. makes version pinning impossible.
the version needs to be at least 2.0.2.0. e.g. 2.0.1.0 will not work.

If they provide value as a sample (for a language runtime) then I suggest we move them to samples.  I understand, as we discussed yesterday, that only 1 gets installed (i.e., the existing .js ones), but we do not want to encourage people to keep writing redundant "utils" just to show how its done in a diff. language do we?

at the very least I would like to separate the ones that we actually install from those we dont (and are really just examples) in some way...  either by moving them to another subdir, or to samples under some subdir.

I just saw that 2.1.0.0-1ppa~trusty is the latest (and now only) release.

So if we relax to 2.1.\* it should be fine.. until they release 2.2

Using 2.\* installs 2.1.0.0 which it works for us

See [here](https://launchpad.net/~ansible/+archive/ubuntu/ansible)

I guess we will be safe. We had problems with 2.0.1.0 that were fixed in 2.0.2.0. So as long as they don't screw up and put up 2.0.1.0 again using "2.*" will work ok. I wonder why they don't just keep old versions for some time longer.
@rabbah You can merge this. @csantanapr and I have discussed on #530 that 2.\* hopefully never installs 2.0.1.0 again. I cannot merge into master myself.

well not everything under samples directory get install either.
I think we should not install any samples/examples. 
We should find a better and easy way for users to get any or all sample/example installed/copy in their namespace.

@domdom82 thanks for the review.
Running PG and local Vagrant build just to be sure, and then it will be ready to merge
@mrutkows I think we can move them to samples, when we move catalog folder to own repo in #434 , at that time the corresponding tests also can be updated.

That is the point, samples do not get installed and it would be good to move similar actions to "samples" package.  The goal of both the "utils" and "system" packages should be to not hold/hold/reposit actions that do not get installed.  I agree that when we move the dirs. as part of repo. move we should relocate if we wish to preserve them.
Thanks!

I want to reproduce a docker specific error locally, that's why I put it up for discussion whether to downgrade or not - I think it would make sense to keep the local development environment in sync with the rest of the project.
Agreeing to @danielfederschmidt. We should keep the whole pipeline in sync, including dev envs.
rebased and merged 364e61ad03372eb80e0ba2b09e18df8b09e8859f
@daisy-ycguo - while not part of the issue. do you think you can clarify `$BASEURL` which is used in the doc but not defined?

@perryibm This PR allows us to pass-through the apparmor policy for user containers dynamically per deployment. The policy itself is not part of this PR and will be delivered additionally. I've choosen to make the policy configurable because we want to have a specific policy for whisk instead of overriding `docker-default` policy, which allows us to be more restrictive on user containers.  I kept `docker-default` policy as the default for user containers if not overridden in the environment definition. However, `docker-default` will apply to the invoker itself.

I was able to reproduce the issue using the following sequence of actions:
- Checkout openwhisk's master branch
- Create a new VM using the Vagrantfile in `/tools/vagrant/custom` and a cloudant db
- Deploy openwhisk via `ant clean build deploy`
- Execute `docker stop` for the registrator container
- Execute `docker rm` for the registrator container

Our issue seems to be related to https://github.com/docker/docker/issues/17823 
and https://github.com/docker/docker/issues/17902
where host's `/var/lib/docker/containers` is also added as a data volume to a container and 1.9 is also used.

Next steps:
- Check whether issue occurs with docker 1.10 / other kernel versions 
- Find a solution on how to go forward
@rabbah @ChrBi , thanks for your review, I'll first to review the doc mentioned by rabbah, and modify code according to your comments before I submit.

what about we list all the webhooks created by the user, and check if the callback url contains the trigger name, we then delete the  corresponding webhook. In this way, we don’t have to persist the webhook id somewhere.

what about we list all the webhooks created by the user, and check if the callback url contains the trigger name, we then delete the corresponding webhook. In this way, we don’t have to persist the webhook id somewhere. The bad is we delete all the webhooks with the trigger name.
I'm not able to assign someone for review, @rabbah could you take a look?

Suggested solution:
- we add option calls to the `routes()` in `RestAPIs.scala`. With ajax and Cross-domain it is not possible to pass the Authentication-Header (on OPTION-request).
- Because we do not know if the user is allowed to get information about this action, we only respond with the wildcard for allowed origins and the following headers on OPTION calls:

```
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Access-Control-Allow-Headers: Authorization,content-type
```

The second header is needed to allow Authorization- and content-type header on second call.
- The OPTION-call is followed by the normal POST call. This request includes the Authorization. We do send `Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *` in the response again. We also decided not to set a custom URL, because this would only have effect on calls from web browsers.

> This request includes the Authorization. We do not send any headers in the response, because this request is already allowed because of the header from OPTION response.

This implies, that the user wants to make a call that is "preflighted" by an OPTIONS request, right? That will be true for action invocations, since they make a POST with Content-Type application/json. ~~`GET` on /actions for example won't be preflighted, hence it won't get the correct `Access-Control` headers?~~  They will in-fact be preflighted because we need to send `Authorization` as you mentioned.

I updated my comment above. We need to send the Header in POST response again. That was my mistake.
We would suggest to send the header only on post requests. Or does anyone think, that we should also support getting and updating entities?
I don't see any harm in supporting the whole API and I as a user would expect that i can do all of the API operations from any client.

This would be much easier.
We commit our current state for review, and if it's OK, we will write our tests.

https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/compare/master...ChrBi:corsHeader?expand=1&w=1

@danielfederschmidt I know this is not directly related, but why do we install docker-py in ansible.sh instead of docker.sh ?

@csantanapr I'm not entirely sure but I guess that we use features contained in the ansible docker module which requires docker-py to be installed [1]. This follows the same pattern as gradle.sh where the software-properties-common and the python-software-properties package are installed before gradle is installed.

[1] http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/docker_module.html
Merged with bc959d6cb2f760ec4d23e6bce0c64cc7716aa018

@rabbah The code is ready and based on the history of the `catalog` folder you seem like the right person to assign this to.  The only question I have is whether or not this one action warrants an entirely new package.

Hi
Andreas assigned a task to me and Sebastian to implement IMAP for incoming emails. I have created a service provider for that, it is now available , to use it :
- The feed action is available as a public action within my namespace: 
  `/talmaam@de.ibm.com_mainSpace/imapFeed`
- Create trigger and pass the needed parameters: 
  `wsk trigger create imapTrigger -p user 'EMAIL' -p pass 'PASSWORD' -p host 'HOST' -p mailbox 'MAILBOX' --feed imapFeed 
  `
  **Example:** 
  `wsk trigger create imapTrigger -p user 'almaamaritest@gmail.com' -p pass 'XXXX' -p host 'imap.gmail.com' -p mailbox 'INBOX' --feed imapFeed
  `

>  i'd suggest to prioritize the event source higher than the action

why?   sending emails is a very useful facility.
This pull request is ready for review now.

a precanned action is essentially 'just' a code sample (of which there a many available here, for simple copy & paste: https://sendgrid.com/docs/Integrate/Code_Examples/index.html) . however, having an email-based feed implemented is non-trivial value-add to openwhisk. it's good to have an action, but i just don't see the priority as being as high.
We should mention if the action will be executed with python 2 or python 3.

@csantanapr  @danielfederschmidt  the docker engine is not ansible related. The docker engine is not installed with ansible. 
The `docker-py` pip package which is used by ansible for deploying docker container is covered in `prereq.yml` playbook, and of course in `ansible.sh` as well (which is soon obsolete once ansible is ready, no ant anymore)

personal preferences are for Python and to see all bash scripts replaced
some day.
